name: Rome
intro_vibe: The Eternal City: A chaotic open-air museum where ancient ruins meet Vespa traffic and perfect pasta.

general_info.description: Rome is overwhelming in the best way. It is a collision of 3,000 years of history, gritty street life, and world-class food. It is noisy, messy, and stunningly beautiful. Don't expect efficiency; expect dolce vita.

etiquette_tips: No Cappuccino After 11am: Milk is for breakfast. Ordering a cappuccino after lunch marks you instantly as a tourist. Order espresso (caffè) instead.
Coperto Charge: Restaurants add a €2-3 'cover charge' per person for bread/table. This is normal. Tipping is NOT required (leave €1-2 coins if you want).
Dress Code: Shoulders and knees MUST be covered to enter St. Peter's or the Pantheon. Carry a scarf.
Ticket Validation: Validate bus/tram tickets in the yellow machines. Inspectors show up when you least expect them.
Dinner Time: Dinner starts at 8:30pm or 9pm. Restaurants are empty at 7pm.
Don't Touch Produce: In markets, do not touch fruit/veg with bare hands. Ask the vendor or wear the provided plastic glove.
Water Fountains (Nasoni): The street water fountains flow constantly with cold, clean volcanic water. Drink from them!

neighborhoods.name: Trastevere
neighborhoods.description: Ivy-covered buildings, cobblestone streets, and intense nightlife. Beautiful by day, a street party by night.

neighborhoods.name: Monti
neighborhoods.description: Rome's hipster village right next to the Colosseum. Vintage shops, wine bars, and artisans. Where locals hang out.

neighborhoods.name: Centro Storico
neighborhoods.description: The heart of Baroque Rome. Pantheon, Navona, Trevi. Stunning, crowded, and expensive.

neighborhoods.name: Prati
neighborhoods.description: Upscale, wide avenues, and high-end shopping near the Vatican. Great for luxury shopping and calmer dining.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
details: Coffee Bar Rule: Price is regulated at the bar (€1.10), but doubles if you sit at a table. Drink standing up like a local.
Cobblestones (Sanpietrini): They destroy suitcases and heels. Wear comfortable sneakers.
August Shutdown: The city empties in mid-August. Many non-tourist restaurants close for 2 weeks.
Pickpockets: Be extremely alert on Bus 64 (to Vatican) and the Metro. Keep bags front-facing.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: Walk whenever possible. Public transit is notoriously unreliable.
details: Walking: The historic center is compact and walkable. It is the best way to see the city.
Metro: Only 3 lines (A, B, C). Useful for Colosseum/Vatican, useless for the historic center.
Bus: Often late, crowded, or on strike. Use CityMapper to track them.
Taxi: Do not hail on the street (they won't stop). Go to a Taxi Rank or use the 'FreeNow' app. Uber is expensive.

logistics.title: Safety & Scams
details: The Bracelet Scam: Men will try to tie a 'free' bracelet on your wrist then demand money. Keep hands in pockets.
Gladiator Photos: Costumed gladiators at the Colosseum will aggressively demand €20-50 for a photo. Ignore them.
Termini Station: The area around the main train station is gritty at night. Be vigilant.

must_eat.description: Rome's holy dish. Egg yolks, Pecorino Romano cheese, Guanciale (cured pork cheek), and black pepper. NO cream. Cream is a crime here.
Pasta with Pecorino cheese and black pepper. Simple ingredients, incredibly hard to master. Creamy, spicy, salty perfection.
Rectangular pizza sold by weight. Point to the one you want, show them how much, and eat it on the street. Try Bonci Pizzarium.
Fried rice ball stuffed with ragù and mozzarella. Rome's favorite street snack. Break it open to see the 'telephone wire' of cheese.
Sweet breakfast bun filled with an insane amount of fresh whipped cream. Messy and delicious. Get it at Regoli.
Look for 'Artigianale'. Avoid places with mountains of brightly colored fluff (tourist traps). Good gelato has natural colors and is kept in covered tins.
Jewish-style deep fried artichokes. Crispy like potato chips on the outside, tender inside. A specialty of the Roman Ghetto.

items.description: The world's largest amphitheater. Book tickets WEEKS in advance or you will be stuck outside. The underground tour is worth it.
The best-preserved building from ancient Rome. The dome is an engineering miracle. Entry is now paid, book online.
The political heart of the ancient empire. It's a ruin maze—hiring a guide or audio guide is essential to understand what you're seeing.
The center of the Catholic world. Massive, opulent, and free (but the line is long). Go at 7am to avoid the wait.
Home to the Sistine Chapel. It is incredibly crowded. Book the 'Early Morning' or 'Night' tour to actually enjoy it.
Rome's most famous baroque fountain. Tradition says throw a coin to return to Rome. Go at sunrise or 2am to avoid the crush.
Famous staircase meeting point. Note: It is now illegal to sit on the steps (police will whistle at you).

affiliate_products.title: Italy Travel Adapter (Type L)
affiliate_products.reason: Italy has a unique 3-pin plug (Type L) alongside the standard Euro plug. Older buildings often ONLY have Type L.

affiliate_products.title: Anti-Theft Crossbody Bag
affiliate_products.reason: Pickpockets on buses and metros are skilled. A bag with locking zippers gives you peace of mind.

affiliate_products.title: Reusable Water Bottle
affiliate_products.reason: Rome has thousands of free, cold water fountains (nasoni). Don't buy plastic bottles; refill yours for free.
